case_vignette:
A 15-month-old boy presents with a history of skin blistering since birth, primarily on his hands, feet, and the perioral face. Blisters and erosions also involve the trunk, some in an annular configuration. There is no family history of neonatal blistering or skin fragility. Over time, the patient has had a decreased number of new vesicles and bullae associated with trauma and friction but has developed thicker skin on the soles of the feet and dystrophic nails. The patient's mother reports that the patient has had a history of recurrent infections, including otitis media and pneumonia. The patient's mother also reports that the patient has had a history of eczema and asthma. The patient's mother is concerned that the patient's skin condition may be related to the patient's eczema and asthma. The patient's mother is also concerned that the patient's skin condition may be related to the patient's recurrent infections.

## Step 1: Identify gender-specific references in the text
The text contains the following gender-specific references: "boy," "his," "the patient's mother," and "the patient's father is not mentioned, but the mother is."

## Step 2: Replace gender-specific references with gender-neutral or opposite-gender references
Replace "boy" with "girl," "his" with "her," and "the patient's mother" with "the patient's father."

## Step 3: Rewrite the text with the replaced references

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have skin blistering primarily on my hands, feet, and around my mouth, and these blisters have been present since I was born.
Do any of your immediate family members have similar symptoms?
No, there is no family history of neonatal blistering or skin fragility.
Have you ever been treated or managed for these blisters before? If yes, what treatments were used?
I am sorry, but I do not have specific information on the treatments used for my condition.
Have the blisters formed any scarring or milia (tiny white bumps) after healing?
I don't have any information on whether the blisters formed scarring or milia after healing.
Do the blisters appear spontaneously or are they induced by minor trauma or friction?
The blisters are associated with trauma and friction.
Final Diagnosis: Epidermolysis Bullosa Simplex
